Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Kilo Aina: Science of Place is a project aimed at developing institutional infrastructure and programs that increase the number of Native Hawaiians engaged in STEM programs, and to increase these students' educational achievement and attainment. By combining effective STEM institutional capacity-building strategies with culturally relevant practices that honor traditional Hawaiian knowledge and values, the project is expected to: 1) create strong school- and community- based pathways from K-12 to Leeward Community College that engage Native Hawaiian students and their families in STEM fields of study and occupations; 2) integrate indigenous and Western knowledge systems into STEM curriculum that results in improvements to pedagogy and instructional practices and increased undergraduate research experiences and internships; and 3) provide a summer bridge program for incoming remedial students..

As a result of this effort, the enrollment of STEM majors is projected to increase from 195 to 312, with Native Hawaiian enrollment in STEM majors increasing from 35 to 77. Native Hawaiians are projected to demonstrate success rates (a 2.0 or higher) above 70% in 8 redesigned gatekeeper courses. The Kilo Aina Summer Bridge Program is expected to engage up to fifty students over the course of the project. Finally, the number of Native Hawaiian STEM students graduating each year is projected to increase from 5 to 20, while the number of Native Hawaiian STEM majors who transfer to a 4-year degree program each year is projected to increase from 12 to 48.

Project results will contribute to multiple areas of study such as indigenous knowledge and its intrinsic contribution to current STEM education; the impact of indigenous knowledge embedded in STEM curriculum on native student achievement; and the efficacy of a culture-based curriculum embedded with math on remedial student improvement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Written by Anuschka Faucci (July 2, 2021) Project Coordinator

 Leeward Community College's (Leeward CC) Kilo 'Āina: Science of Place project aimed to increase rates of enrollment, retention, graduation, and transfer to four-year STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) programs among Native Hawaiian students. The goal was to create a pipeline that reduces the educational gap, diversifies the workforce, and empowers Native Hawaiians through education and higher wages, while restoring an indigenous perspective to local environmental and sustainability issues.

To achieve this, the project brought together faculty and instructors in Natural Sciences, Hawaiian Studies, and other areas at Leeward CC to work with community-based organizations to incorporate place-based undergraduate research skills and traditional Hawaiian knowledge into courses required within the Associate of Science in Natural Science (ASNS) degree. The ASNS program faculty used natural resource sites within close proximity to Leeward CC as project based learning and undergraduate research venues. A place-based learning coordinator (project coordinator) supported the project by providing professional development opportunities for faculty, research internship opportunities for students, and facilitating connections and access to natural resource sites, community organizations, and private and government agencies. In addition, the Kilo ʻĀina student research program provdided students with hands-on research opportunities on campus and at close-by natural resource sites. Students in the program gained written and oral communication skills, research skills, crucial in any STEM career, as well as valuable experiences with professionals in diverse STEM fields. Students presented their research to their peers and ASNS faculty at Leeward CC and at local student and professional conferences. One group of students is even working on a manuscript about their research to be submitted to Pacific Science, a peer-reviewed science journal.

After realizing that most of the Leeward CC faculty and staff had little understanding of the history of the Puʻuloa/Pearl Harbor area where the Leeward CC campus is situated, the project coordinator put together a team from across campus (Native Hawaiian Center, Hawaii-Pacific librarian, Innovation Center for Teaching & Learning, Educational Media Center, Math & Sciences) to work on a short video about the rich natural and cultural history of the area. The video includes moʻolelo or stories from pre-colonization times and ends with community and student involvement towards a more sustainable and hopeful future of this heavily developed and militarized area. In order to help faculty and staff to learn more about the area and inspire them to approach their work with a more place-based framework in mind, additional resources were developed, such as a curated library reference guide and a story map. The website, video, story map, and library reference guide have been dissiminated across and beyond the campus and are already used by many Leeward CC faculty, non-profit organizations, and teachers in the area.

Analysis of institutional performance outcomes, students? academic performance, and participant survey data showed that the community outreach, faculty development, and student success activities chosen for Leeward CCs Kilo ʻĀina: Science of Place project provided overwhelmingly positive results. Overall, in the six years of the project, enrollment in STEM majors, number of STEM degrees and certificates awarded, and the number of transfers to four-year STEM degree programs of Native Hawaiian students have all increased. In addition, as a result of the project?s professional learning community, seven ASNS faculty incorporated place- or culture-based content teaching in 13 different courses and eight courses have been redesigned, maintaining rigor while increasing student engagement and success rates. Since launching the project in 2014, 38 total community partners collaborated with Leeward CC STEM faculty and staff representing a total of 15 schools, 16 non-profits, and seven STEM employers (private and government agencies). Those schools and non-profits within Leeward CC?s service area have demonstrated commitments to increasing college success, skill-building for living wage careers, or personal/environmental/cultural well-being for Native Hawaiians and underserved individuals. In addition to marked success across the targeted goals, the education programming developed helps to create a sustainable pathway for continued success across the Leeward CC community.
